paragraphs.text: Our 'impartial' broadcasters have become mouthpieces of the elite.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: When people say they have no politics, it means that their politics aligns with the status quo
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: None of us are unbiased
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: none removed from the question of power
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We are social creatures who absorb the outlook and opinions of those with whom we associate, and unconciously echo them
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Objectivity is impossible
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The illusion of neutrality is one of the reasons for the rotten state of journalism, as those who might have been expected to hold power to account drift thoughtlessly into its arms
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: until I came across the scandal currently erupting in Canada, I hadn't understood just how quickly standards are falling
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In 2013 reporters at CBC, Canada's equivalent of the BBC, broke a major story
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: They discovered that RBC - Royal Bank of Canada - had done something cruel and unusual even by banking standards
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It was obliging junior staff to train a group of temporary foreign workers
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: who would then be given the staff's jobs
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Just after the first report was aired, according to the website Canadaland, something odd happened
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: journalists preparing to expand on the investigation were summoned to a conference call with Amanda Lang, CBC's senior business correspondent and a star presenter
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The reporters she spoke to say she repeatedly attempted to scuttle the story, dismissing it as trivial and dull
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: They were astonished
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But not half as astonished as
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: when
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they discovered the following, unpublished facts
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: First
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: that Lang had spoken at a series of events run or sponsored by RBC
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: for which she appears, on one occasion, to have been paid around 15,000 Canadian dollars
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Second
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: that she was booked to speak at an event sponsored by the outsourcing company the bank had hired to implement the cruel practice exposed by her colleagues
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Third
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: that her partner is a board member at RBC
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Lang then interviewed the bank's chief executive on her own show
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: When he dismissed the story as unfair and misleading
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: she did not challenge him
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That evening she uncritically repeated his talking points on CBC's main current affairs programme
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Her interests, again, were not revealed
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Then she wrote a comment article for the Globe and Mail newspaper suggesting that her colleagues' story arose from an outdated suspicion of business, was dangerous to Canada's interests, and was nothing but "a sideshow"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Here's what she said about the bank's employment practices:"It's called capitalism, and it isn't a dirty word."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Canadaland, which exposed Lang's conflicts last week, found that other journalists at the broadcaster were furious, but too frightened to speak on the record
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: after CBC tried to dismiss the scandal as "half-truths based on anonymous sources"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Kathy Tomlinson, the reporter who had broken the story about the bank, bravely spoke publicly to the website
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The following morning, staff in her office arrived to find this message spelt out in magnets on their fridge:"Jesse Brown snitches get stitches"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Jesse Brown is Canadaland's founder
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: CBC refused to answer my questions
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: I have not had a response from Lang
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It amazes me that she remains employed by CBC
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which has so far done nothing but bluster and berate its critics
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This is grotesque
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But it's symptomatic of a much wider problem in journalism
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: those who are supposed to scrutinise the financial and political elite are embedded within it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Many belong to a service-sector aristocracy, wedded metaphorically (sometimes literally) to finance
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Often unwittingly, they amplify the voices of the elite, while muffling those raised against it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A study by academics at the Cardiff School of Journalism examined the BBC Today programme's reporting of the bank bailouts in 2008
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It discovered that the contributors it chose were "almost completely dominated by stockbrokers, investment bankers, hedge fund managers and other City voices
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Civil society voices or commentators who questioned the benefits of having such a large finance sector were almost completely absent from coverage."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The financiers who had caused the crisis were asked to interpret it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The same goes for discussions about the deficit and the perceived need for austerity
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The debate has been dominated by political and economic elites
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: while alternative voices - arguing that the crisis has been exaggerated, or that instead of cuts, the government should respond with Keynesian spending programmes or taxes on financial transactions, wealth or land- have scarcely been heard
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Those priorities have changed your life
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the BBC helped to shape the political consensus under which so many are now suffering
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The BBC's business reporting breaks its editorial guidelines every day by failing to provide alternative viewpoints
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Every weekday morning, the Today programme grovels to business leaders for 10 minutes
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It might occasionally challenge them on the value or viability of their companies, but hardly ever on their ethics
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Corporate critics are shut out of its business coverage - and almost all the rest
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: On BBC News at Six, the Cardiff researchers found, business representatives outnumbered trade union representatives by 19 to one
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: "The BBC tends to reproduce a Conservative, Eurosceptic, pro-business version of the world," the study said
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: This, remember, is where people turn when they don't trust the corporate press
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: While the way in which the media handle the stories that are covered is bad enough
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the absence of coverage is even worse
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: an issue does not divide the main political parties
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: , it vanishes from view
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: though the parties now disagree on hardly anything
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Another study reveals a near total collapse of environmental coverage on ITV and BBC news: it declined from 2.5% (ITV) and 1.6% (BBC) of total airtime in 2007 to, respectively, 0.2% and 0.3% in 2014
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: There were as many news stories on these outlets about Madeleine McCann in 2014 - seven years after her disappearance - as there were about all environmental issues put together
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Those entrusted to challenge power are the loyalists of power
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They rage against social media and people such as Russell Brand, without seeing that the popularity of alternatives is a response to their own failures: their failure to expose the claims of the haut monde, their failure to enlist a diversity of opinion, their failure to permit the audience to see that another world is possible
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: even the public sector broadcasters parrot the talking points of the elite
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: what hope is there for informed democratic choice?
paragraphs.label: assumption
